elements.content: Three new Mn(II)−azido polymeric complexes [MnL1(N3)2·CH3OH] n (1) (L1 = 1-(2-pyridyl)-1-amino-4-(6-bromo-2-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene), [MnL2(N3)2] n (2a) and [Mn2(L2)2(N3)4] n (2b) (L2 = 1-(2-pyridyl)-1-amino-4-benzyl-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) have been synthesized and crystallographically characterized, and their magnetic properties are studied. Complexes 1 and 2b show similar one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymeric structure, in which Mn(II) ions are alternately bridged by two end-to-end (EE) and two end-on (EO) azido ligands, resulting in zigzag Mn(II)−azido chains. Complex 2a has a 1D structure, and the Mn(II) ions are connected by double EO azido ligands, forming a neutral 1D uniform chain. Standing in their mother liquor for ca. 2 weeks or more, 2a is transformed to 2b completely. The structures of 2a and 2b are characterized, and the quite different magnetic properties based on this transformation of kinetic favored phase to thermodynamic favored phase are discussed. Magnetic analyses reveal that alternating ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions are mediated through the alternating EO and EE azido bridges, and the J F and J AF parameters are 7.8(1) and −10.8(1) for complex 1, respectively, 7.7(4) and −11.2(1) cm−1 for complex 2b, respectively. For 2a, on the contrary, magnetic analyses reveal that the ferromagnetic coupling interactions are mediated through the double EO azido bridges, and the J F is 1.4 cm−1.

elements.content: Three azido-bridged Mn(II) complexes have been prepared with similar open-chain diazine Schiff-base as auxiliary ligands and characterized crystallographically and magnetically. A rare phenomenon of kinetic to thermodynamic transformation was observed and the distinct magnetic properties based on different crystal structures were studied.
elements.clean_text: Three azido-bridged Mn(II) complexes have been prepared with similar open-chain diazine Schiff-base as auxiliary ligands and characterized crystallographically and magnetically. A rare phenomenon of kinetic to thermodynamic transformation was observed and the distinct magnetic properties based on different crystal structures were studied.

elements.content: In recent years, great efforts have been devoted to the rational design and synthesis of new metal-organic networks in the field of crystal engineering with the driving force of intriguing architectures and novel functionalities such as gas storage, photoluminescent, and magnetic properties. As for the molecule-based magnets, their properties depend on the structures including the coordination bonding and even weak interactions, encounter ions, the effects of guest molecules and even some chemical or physical stimulation. However, the structures and magnetic properties mainly depend on the properties of the bridging ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, great efforts have been devoted to the rational design and synthesis of new metal-organic networks in the field of crystal engineering with the driving force of intriguing architectures and novel functionalities such as gas storage, photoluminescent, and magnetic properties. As for the molecule-based magnets, their properties depend on the structures including the coordination bonding and even weak interactions, encounter ions, the effects of guest molecules and even some chemical or physical stimulation. However, the structures and magnetic properties mainly depend on the properties of the bridging ligands.

elements.content: In this context, the azido-bridged complexes have attracted intense interest, due to the coordination versatility of the azido bridge and the magnetic diversity of the complexes. The azido ligand can link two or more metal ions in various modes, μ2-1,1 (end-on, EO), μ2-1,3 (end-to-end EE), μ3-1,1,3, and others (Scheme ). Furthermore, these modes may simultaneously exist in the same complex in various alternating sequences or coexist with other bridging groups. The azido ligand can also act as an efficient and versatile magnetic coupler mediating ferro- or antiferromagnetic coupling according to its coordination mode (end-on EO or end-to-end EE). From the magnetic point of view, the end-to-end mode always gives rise to antiferromagnetic interactions, while the end-on mode promotes ferromagnetic interactions. These features, in conjunction with the presence of other organic coligands, have led to many one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D, respectively) azido-bridged complexes with interesting polymeric topologies and/or magnetic properties. In the Mn(II) (S = 5/2) azido system, for instance, an increasing number of 1D, 2D, and sometimes 3D polymers have been obtained in the presence of other organic coligands, and the coligands used thus far have been mainly pyridyl-based neutral ligands such as 2,2′-bipy, 1,10-phen, pyrazine, 4,4′-bipy and their analogues, with only a few exceptions that contain carboxylate groups. As for the bulk magnetic properties of the Mn(II) azido system, different phenomena, including ferromagnetism, antiferromagnetism, metamagnetism, weak ferromagnetism, and paramagnetism, have been recognized, and magnetostructural correlations have been studied. In our continuous research toward molecule-based magnets, we try to explore the effect of the open-chain diazine Schiff-base ligands (Scheme ) introduced into the azido-bridged transition metal system. Recently, with this kind of open-chain diazine ligands−azido systems, we have obtained several 1D, 2D, and 3D Mn(II) and Cd(II) polymers with interesting structures and/or magnetic properties. In this paper, we report the synthesis, crystal structures, and magnetic properties of three new 1D Mn(II) azido-bridged complexes, [Mn(L1)(N3)2·CH3OH] n (1) and [MnL2(N3)2] n (2a) and [Mn2(L2)2(N3)4] n (2b), where L1 = 1-(2-pyridyl)-1-amino-4-(6-bromo-2-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene and L2 = 1-(2-pyridyl)-1-amino-4-benzyl-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene. While complexes 1 and 2b are 1D coordination polymers with alternating double EE and double EO bridges, 2a is a 1D coordination polymer with a uniform double EO azido-bridged Mn(II) chains. Allowing crystals of 2a to stand in their mother liquor results in a quantitatively transformation to 2b, accompanied by changes in color and morphology. This illustrates an interesting phenomenon of the transformation from a kinetically favored phase (2a) to a thermodynamically stable phase (2b), which may involve dissolution and recrystallization. Magnetic investigations revealed alternating ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions through the alternating EO and EE azido bridges in complexes 1 and 2b and ferromagnetic interactions through the EO azido bridges in complex 2a.

elements.content:
All the starting chemicals were of AR grade and used as purchased without further purification. The ligands L1,2 were prepared according to the literature procedures.

Caution! Although not encountered in our experiments, azido complexes of metal ions are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of the material should be prepared, and it should be handled with care.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Synthesis

All the starting chemicals were of AR grade and used as purchased without further purification. The ligands L1,2 were prepared according to the literature procedures. 

Caution! Although not encountered in our experiments, azido complexes of metal ions are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of the material should be prepared, and it should be handled with care.

elements.content: Crystals of 1 were obtained by slow diffusion in an H-shaped tube. A methanol solution (5 mL) containing L1 (0.5 mmol, 0.113 g) and sodium azide (1 mmol, 0.065 g) was added into an arm of the H-shaped tube and a solution of manganese(II) perchlorate hexahydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.181 g) in the same solvent (2 mL) into the other arm, then about 20 mL of methanol was carefully added till the bridge of the tube was filled. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded orange crystals of 1 within 2 weeks. Yield 54.5% based on L1. Anal. Calcd. for C13H14N11MnBrO (%): C, 32.86; H, 2.97; N, 32.43. Found (%): C, 32.51; H, 2.56; N, 32.89. Main IR bands (cm−1): 3445m, 3383m, 3317m, 2099vs, 2064vs, 1630m, 1598m, 1546m, 1434m, 1305m, 1116m, 1013m, 800m, 720m.

elements.content: The complexes 2a and 2b were prepared in the same way as for 1, except using L2 instead of L1. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded red-orange crystals of 2a within 6 days. These red-orange crystals of 2a were stable when they were moved from the mother liquor. If the red-orange crystals were allowed to stand in the mother liquor, they transformed into orange single crystals of 2b gradually. In the H-shaped tube, the red-orange 2a and the orange 2b coexisted for about 10 days. All the red-orange 2a changed into orange 2b completely in 2 weeks or longer. Yield 55.4% for 2b based on ligand L2. Anal. Calcd. for C13H12N10Mn (%) (2a): C, 42.99; H, 3.33; N, 38.56. Found (%): C, 42.97; H, 3.54; N, 38.24. Main IR bands (cm−1): 3424m, 3321m, 3075m, 2100m, 2065vs, 2052vs, 1631m, 1602m, 1542m, 1419m, 1323m, 1015m, 761m, 695m. Anal. Calcd. for C13H12N10Mn (%) (2b): C, 42.99; H, 3.33; N, 38.56. Found (%): C, 43.04; H, 3.43; N, 38.45. Main IR bands (cm−1): 3408m, 3293m, 3076m, 2097vs, 2053vs, 1627s, 1600m, 1577m, 1541m, 1419m, 1014m, 760m, 696m.

[MnL2(N3)2] n  (2a) and [Mn2(L2)2(N3)4] n  (2b)

The complexes 2a and 2b were prepared in the same way as for 1, except using L2 instead of L1. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded red-orange crystals of 2a within 6 days. These red-orange crystals of 2a were stable when they were moved from the mother liquor. If the red-orange crystals were allowed to stand in the mother liquor, they transformed into orange single crystals of 2b gradually. Yield 55.4% for 2b based on ligand L2. Anal. Calcd. for C13H12N10Mn (%) (2a): C, 42.99; H, 3.33; N, 38.56. Found (%): C, 42.97; H, 3.54; N, 38.24. Main IR bands (cm-1): 3424m, 3321m, 3075m, 2100m, 2065vs, 2052vs, 1631m, 1602m, 1542m, 1419m, 1323m, 1015m, 761m, 695m. Anal. Calcd. for C13H12N10Mn (%) (2b): C, 42.99; H, 3.33; N, 38.56. elements.content: The bulk samples were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. While the PXRD pattern measured on 2b is consistent with that calculated from the single-crystal data, suggesting the phase purity of 2b, PXRD measurements indicated that the bulk samples of 2a are always contaminated by a small quantity of an uncharacterized phase, although no impurity is detected by eyes (see the for PXRD patterns). Variable-temperature PXRD measurements on 2a were also performed to detect the potential solid-state transformation from 2a to 2b. We found that 2a cannot transform into 2b in solid state.
elements.clean_text: The bulk samples were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. While the PXRD pattern measured on 2b is consistent with that calculated from the single-crystal data, suggesting the phase purity of 2b, PXRD measurements indicated that the bulk samples of 2a are always contaminated by a small quantity of an uncharacterized phase, although no impurity is detected by eyes (see the  for PXRD patterns). Variable-temperature PXRD measurements on 2a were also performed to detect the potential solid-state transformation from 2a to 2b. We found that 2a cannot transform into 2b in solid state.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna-IR 750 spectrometer equipped with a Nic-Plan Microscope. Magnetic properties of the complexes 1, 2a, and 2b were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS-9 magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on an Elementar Vario EL analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Magna-IR 750 spectrometer equipped with a Nic-Plan Microscope. Magnetic properties of the complexes 1, 2a, and 2b were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS-9 magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Diffraction intensity data of the single crystals for 1, 2a, and 2b were collected at room temperature on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer, equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the Sortav program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined using the riding model. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

Diffraction intensity data of the single crystals for 1, 2a, and 2b were collected at room temperature on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer, equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the Sortav program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were located geometrically and refined using the riding model. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters are summarized in Table .

The IR spectra of complexes 1 and 2b are similar to each other with respect to band positions, shapes, and relative intensities, indicating a very similar structure. The sharp and strong bands at ca. 2097 and 2064 cm−1 indicate the presence of two different azido groups in complexes 1 and 2b. The IR spectrum of complex of 2a also exhibits a strong characteristic absorption (2065 cm−1) for the azido bridges. The absorptions of the CN stretching vibration in the ligands occur as medium bands at ca. 1630 cm−1. The complexes show several strong bands in the range of 3075−3425 cm−1, which can be assigned to the ν(NH) stretching frequency of the NH2 group.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

IR Spectra

The IR spectra of complexes 1 and 2b are similar to each other with respect to band positions, shapes, and relative intensities, indicating a very similar structure. The sharp and strong bands at ca. 2097 and 2064 cm-1 indicate the presence of two different azido groups in complexes 1 and 2b. The IR spectrum of complex of 2a also exhibits a strong characteristic absorption (2065 cm-1) for the azido bridges. The absorptions of the CN stretching vibration in the ligands occur as medium bands at ca. 1630 cm-1. The complexes show several strong bands in the range of 3075-3425 cm-1, which can be assigned to the ν(NH) stretching frequency of the NH2 group.

elements.content: The structure of 1 consists of parallel zigzag chains running parallel to the a direction. The coordination diagram and perspective view of the chain structure is depicted in Figure a,b, and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . The adjacent Mn(II) ions in a chain are related by inversion centers and linked alternately by double end-on and double end-to-end azido bridges with the Mn−N distances in the 2.174(4)−2.256(4) Å range. The EO azido bridges show asymmetric N−N distances [1.194(4) vs 1.147(5) Å], while the EE bridges are essentially symmetric [1.172(5) and 1.176(5) Å]. The cis-octahedral coordination polyhedron around Mn(II) is completed by the two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from the chelating Schiff-base, the bis(bidentate) open-chain diazine Schiff-base ligands only acting as bidentate ligands to occupy certain positions of the metal coordination sphere, with similar Mn−N distances [2.257(3) and 2.253(3) Å]. The rather small bite angle [N1−Mn1−N2, 72.32(11)°] of the Schiff-base ligand defines the largest distortion of the geometry. In the double EO bridged Mn(N3)2Mn moiety, the Mn1−N6−Mn1A−N6A ring is strictly planar due to the existence of the inversion center. The Mn···Mn distance is 3.443 Å, and the Mn1−N6−Mn1A angle is 100.61°, which is among the lowest values for Mn(II) ions with EO azido bridges (100−105°). In the EE bridging moiety, the Mn−N−N angles are 129.5(3)° for Mn1−N9−N10 and 128.2(3)° for Mn1B−N11−N10. The Mn-azido-Mn torsion angle τ, defined by the dihedral angle between the mean planes of Mn1−N9−N10−N11 and Mn1A−N11−N10−N9, is 50.5° (Symmetry code: A, 1 − x, −y, 1 − z). The two EE azido bridges are parallel and thus form a plane, which is characteristic of nearly all polynuclear complexes with double EE azido bridges. The Mn···Mn distances for the EE bridges are 5.416 Å. The Mn(II) ions are 0.728 Å out of the (EE-N3)2 plane, and the dihedral angle δ between this plane and the N9−Mn1−N11A plane is only 26.9°, indicating a chair conformation for the Mn−(N3)2−Mn ring. Both τ and δ in 1 are comparable with the corresponding angles (40−64° for τ and 20−35° for δ) for reported Mn(II) chains with alternating EE and EO bridges. The shortest interchain Mn···Mn distance is 7.769 Å between Mn1 and Mn1B (symmetrical code: B, 1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z), significantly shorter than the corresponding distance for reported Mn(II) chains with alternating EE and EO bridges (8 Å). In the lattice, two strong hydrogen bonds (Table ) are formed between the uncoordinated amine group (NH2) of L1 and the lattice solvent menthol molecule (CH3OH). Weak interchain C−H···N hydrogen bonds also exist between the uncoordinated amine group (NH2) of in L1 and N atom of the EE bridging azido ligands (Figure c). For the ligand L1, the imine group and the bromine ion of the Br-substituted pyridine ring are in the cis-conformation relative to the ligands, and the C−N−N−C torsion angle and the dihedral angles between the two planar pyridylimine groups are 4.31 and 1.2°, respectively, showing an almost coplanar conformation for the whole ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

The structure of 1 consists of parallel zigzag chains running parallel to the a direction. The coordination diagram and perspective view of the chain structure is depicted in Figure a,b, and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . The adjacent Mn(II) ions in a chain are related by inversion centers and linked alternately by double end-on and double end-to-end azido bridges with the Mn-N distances in the 2.174(4)-2.256(4) Å range. The EO azido bridges show asymmetric N-N distances [1.194(4) vs 1.147(5) Å], while the EE bridges are essentially symmetric [1.172(5) and 1.176(5) Å]. The cis-octahedral coordination polyhedron around Mn(II) is completed by the two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from the chelating Schiff-base, the bis(bidentate) open-chain diazine Schiff-base ligands only acting as bidentate ligands to occupy certain positions of the metal coordination sphere, with similar Mn-N distances [2.257(3) and 2.253(3) Å]. The rather small bite angle [N1-Mn1-N2, 72.32(11)°] of the Schiff-base ligand defines the largest distortion of the geometry. In the double EO bridged Mn(N3)2Mn moiety, the Mn1-N6-Mn1A-N6A ring is strictly planar due to the existence of the inversion center. The Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance is 3.443 Å, and the Mn1-N6-Mn1A angle is 100.61°, which is among the lowest values for Mn(II) ions with EO azido bridges (100-105°). In the EE bridging moiety, the Mn-N-N angles are 129.5(3)° for Mn1-N9-N10 and 128.2(3)° for Mn1B-N11-N10. The Mn-azido-Mn torsion angle τ, defined by the dihedral angle between the mean planes of Mn1-N9-N10-N11 and Mn1A-N11-N10-N9, is 50.5° (Symmetry code: A, 1 - x, -y, 1 - z). The two EE azido bridges are parallel and thus form a plane, which is characteristic of nearly all polynuclear complexes with double EE azido bridges. The Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distances for the EE bridges are 5.416 Å. The Mn(II) ions are 0.728 Å out of the (EE-N3)2 plane, and the dihedral angle δ between this plane and the N9-Mn1-N11A plane is only 26.9°, indicating a chair conformation for the Mn-(N3)2-Mn ring. Both τ and δ in 1 are comparable with the corresponding angles (40-64° for τ and 20-35° for δ) for reported Mn(II) chains with alternating EE and EO bridges. The shortest interchain Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance is 7.769 Å between Mn1 and Mn1B (symmetrical code: B, 1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z), significantly shorter than the corresponding distance for reported Mn(II) chains with alternating EE and EO bridges (8 Å). In the lattice, two strong hydrogen bonds (Table ) are formed between the uncoordinated amine group (NH2) of L1 and the lattice solvent menthol molecule (CH3OH). Weak interchain C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds also exist between the uncoordinated amine group (NH2) of in L1 and N atom of the EE bridging azido ligands (Figure c). For the ligand L1, the imine group and the bromine ion of the Br-substituted pyridine ring are in the cis-conformation relative to the ligands, and the C-N-N-C torsion angle and the dihedral angles between the two planar pyridylimine groups are 4.31 and 1.2°, respectively, showing an almost coplanar conformation for the whole ligand.

Complex 2a contains neutral 1D chains constructed by double EO azido bridges linking Mn(II) ions along the c direction. The coordination diagram and perspective view of the chain structure is depicted in Figure , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . The adjacent Mn(II) ions in a chain are related by inversion centers and linked alternately by double end-on azido bridges with the Mn−N distances in the range of 2.161(2)−2.458(2) Å. The EO azido bridges are asymmetric with N−N distances falling in the range of av. 1.206(3)−1.153(3) Å, respectively. The rather small bite angle [N1−Mn1−N2, 73.02(7)°] of the Schiff-base ligand defines the largest distortion of the geometry. In the moiety of Mn(N3)2Mn, the Mn1−N5−Mn1A−N8A ring and Mn1−N5B−Mn1B−N8 are almost coplanar with the mean deviation for ca. 0.068 Å. The Mn···Mn distances are 3.584 Å, and the Mn1−N5−Mn1A and Mn1−N8−Mn1B angles are 100.53(8) and 107.66(8)°, respectively, which are comparable with corresponding parameters for Mn(II) complexes with EO azido bridges (100−105°). The shortest interchain Mn···Mn distance is 8.854 Å between Mn1 and Mn1B (Symmetrical code: B, 2 − x, 2 − y, −z), significantly shorter than the corresponding distances (9.931, 9.267 or 11.521 Å) for reported Mn(II) uniform chains with double EO azido bridges.

Complex 2b also contains neutral 1D parallel zigzag chains linked alternately by double end-on and double end-to-end azido bridges, which is similar to complex 1. The coordination diagram and perspective view of the chain structure is depicted in Figure , and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . The bond distances and angles are similar to those in 1, and the Mn···Mn distances spanned by double end-on and double end-to-end azido bridges are 3.431 and 5.409 Å, respectively. In the double EO bridged Mn(N3)2Mn moiety, the structural data indicate two different EO bridging ligands [Mn1−(N8−N9−N10)−Mn2 and Mn2−(N11−N12−N13)−Mn2], given the similar Mn−N−Mn bridging angles (101.11 vs 100.56°). In the EE bridging moiety, because there are no inversion centers in the double EE moieties, the double EE azido bridges are nonparallel, and the Mn-azido-Mn torsion angles τ for the two azido ligands are 29.92° for N5−N6−N7 and 46.78° for N14−N15−N16, respectively. The shortest interchain Mn···Mn distance is 7.371 Å between Mn2 and Mn2B (symmetrical code: B, −x, −y, 1 − z), also significantly shorter than the corresponding distances for reported Mn(II) uniform chains with double EO bridges. The two crystallographically independent sets of L2 show different conformation. For one set, ligands have an almost coplanar conformation similar to those in complex 1, and the C−N−N−C torsion angle is 5.96° and the dihedral angles between the pyridylimine groups and the phenylimine are 10.80°. For the other set, the ligands show a slightly twisted spiral conformation, and the C−N−N−C torsion angle 10.92° and the dihedral angles between the pyridylimine groups and the phenylimine are 31.50°.

Interestingly, the red-orange single crystals of complex 2a in the mother liquor can be transformed to orange crystals of complex 2b gradually. This suggests that 2a is a kinetically favored phase and that 2b is thermodynamically more stable. The difference in thermodynamic stability may be tentatively related to the structural data. As can be seen in Figures and , the orientation of the Schiff base ligands relative to the Mn(II)−azido chains are as follows: for complex 2a, the phenyl groups are cis to an EO azido bridge; for complex 2b, the opposite situation is observed. As a consequence, the ligands in the double EO azido-bridged chains maybe impose larger steric effect than the double EO and double EE azido-bridged alternate chains.

As can be seen in Figures  and , the orientation of the Schiff base ligands relative to the Mn(II)-azido chains are as follows: for complex 2a, the phenyl groups are cis to an EO azido bridge; for complex 2b, the opposite situation is observed. As a consequence, the ligands in the double EO azido-bridged chains maybe impose larger steric effect than the double EO and double EE azido-bridged alternate chains.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1 and 2b were measured in the 2−300 K temperature range and are shown as χM and χM T versus T plots in Figure . The experimental χM T values for complexes 1 and 2b at 300 K are 4.03 and 4.07 emu mol−1 K, respectively, somewhat lower than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol−1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products decrease monotonically and tend to zero at low temperature, while the χM values increase to the rounded maximums at about 50 K and then decrease rapidly on further cooling. The final increase at very low temperature may be due to the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurities. These features indicate a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction in these complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1 and 2b were measured in the 2-300 K temperature range and are shown as χM and χM T versus T plots in Figure . The experimental χM T values for complexes 1 and 2b at 300 K are 4.03 and 4.07 emu mol-1 K, respectively, somewhat lower than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol-1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products decrease monotonically and tend to zero at low temperature, while the χM values increase to the rounded maximums at about 50 K and then decrease rapidly on further cooling. The final increase at very low temperature may be due to the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurities. These features indicate a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction in these complexes.

elements.content: According to the structural data, these complexes should exhibit alternating ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions mediated by double EO and double EE azido bridges, respectively. To simulate the experimental magnetic behavior, we used the theoretical model proposed by Cortés et al. for alternating F/AF S = 5/2 chains The nearest neighbor exchange interactions are described by the spin Hamiltonian (eq ): H = − J 1 ∑ 2 i S 2 i + 1 − J 2 ∑ S 2 i + 1 S 2 i + 2 where J 1 and J 2 correspond to the alternating exchange constants for the EE and EO superexchange pathways, respectively, and the S operators are treated as classical spins. The deduced expression of the molar susceptibility χchain is χ M = [ N g 2 β 2 S ( S + 1 ) / ( 3 k T ) ] { [ ( 1 + u 1 + u 2 + u 1 u 2 ) / ( 1 − u 1 u 2 ) ] ( 1 − ρ ) + ρ } with u i = coth[J i S(S + 1)/kT] − kT/[J i S(S + 1)] (i = 1, 2), where N is Avogadro’s number, β is the Bohr magneton, k is the Boltzmann constant, and ρ is a parameter related to the amount of paramagnetic impurities to account for the increase of χM in the low temperature. The least-squares fits of the experimental data above 20 K to the above equation were acceptable, but when the low-temperature data were included in the fits, the agreement was not satisfactory, probably due to the presence of interchain antiferromagnetic interactions and/or zero-field splitting of the Mn(II) ion. Taking this into account, we introduced a Weiss constant Θ by replacing T with T − Θ in eq (the T parameters in the u i equation are not replaced). Following this approximation and fixing g at 2.0), satisfactory simulations were obtained in the whole temperature range. The least-squares fits of the experimental data leads to J F = 7.8(1) cm−1, J AF = −10.8(1) cm−1, Θ = −2.7 K with ρ = 0.006 for 1, and J F = 7.7(4) cm−1, J AF = −11.2(1) cm−1, Θ = −2.2 K with ρ = 0.009. J F and J AF are associated with the exchange coupling through EO and EE azido bridges, respectively. The magnetostructural comparison of Mn(II) chain compounds with alternating double EO and double EE azido bridges has been reported in previous studies. The general trends are that the ferromagnetic interaction in the double EO bridging fragments increases with the Mn−N−Mn bridging angle and that the antiferromagnetic interaction in the double EE bridging fragments decreases when the distortion of the Mn-(N3)2-Mn ring from planarity to the chair conformation becomes more significant. It is noteworthy that the present complex 1 follows the general trend well. Because the Mn-(EE-N3)2-Mn ring in complex 2b adopts an unusual twist conformation with the two linear azido bridges crossing each other, magnetic analyses have suggested that an antiferromagnetic interaction is mediated via this type of double EE bridge, but more experimental examples are needed for magnetostructural correlation studies.

elements.content: Because of the kinetic-to-thermodynamic transformation, it is difficult to obtain very pure sample of 2a. PXRD measurements indicated the bulk samples of 2a are always contaminated by a small quantity of an uncharacterized phase. But taking into account the ferromagnetic character of 2a (vide infra), the contribution of the small amount of impurity to the magnetic susceptibility should be negligible, and as will be seen below, the magnetic analyses based on the structure of 2a are satisfactory. But the preliminary magnetic properties are studied in the temperature range of 2−300 K. The experimental χM T values for complex 2a at 300 K are 5.31 emu mol−1 K, larger than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol−1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products increase monotonically and smoothly to the maximum at about 27 K, and then decreases rapidly. The χM values increase monotonically, and below 3 K, the χM values decrease rapidly on further cooling (Figure ). These features indicate a dominant ferromagnetic interaction in complex 2a.

elements.content: With g fixed at 2.0 for S = 5/2 system, the best least-squares fit parameters gave J = 1.42 cm −1, zJ′ = −0.05 cm−1 for 2a. The magnetic and structural data of the known double EO azido-bridged Mn(II) chain complexes including 2a, which all exhibit ferromagnetic intrachain interactions, are summarized in Table . It has been suggested that the Mn−N−Mn bridging angle (θ) is the main factor that controls the magnetic interaction between metal ions. The ferromagnetic exchange appears to increase with an increase of the bridging angle (starting from 100°) involved in the exchange pathway. This trend is consistent with the density functional calculations on model Mn(II) complexes performed by Ruiz et al. This calculation predicts that a crossover between ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions occurs at θ = 98°, and that the ferromagnetic interaction increases when the Mn−N−Mn bridging angle increases beyond 98°. However, for 2a, the J value seems to be too small for the relatively large Mn−N−Mn bridging angle. The deviation may be due to the influence of other structural parameters, as well as the presence of the impurity in the sample.
elements.clean_text: With g fixed at 2.0 for S = 5/2 system, the best least-squares fit parameters gave J = 1.42 cm -1, zJ' = -0.05 cm-1 for 2a. The magnetic and structural data of the known double EO azido-bridged Mn(II) chain complexes including 2a, which all exhibit ferromagnetic intrachain interactions, are summarized in Table . It has been suggested that the Mn-N-Mn bridging angle (θ) is the main factor that controls the magnetic interaction between metal ions. The ferromagnetic exchange appears to increase with an increase of the bridging angle (starting from 100°) involved in the exchange pathway. This trend is consistent with the density functional calculations on model Mn(II) complexes performed by Ruiz et al. This calculation predicts that a crossover between ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions occurs at θ = 98°, and that the ferromagnetic interaction increases when the Mn-N-Mn bridging angle increases beyond 98°. However, for 2a, the J value seems to be too small for the relatively large Mn-N-Mn bridging angle. The deviation may be due to the influence of other structural parameters, as well as the presence of the impurity in the sample.

The double EO azido-bridged Mn···Mn distances.

Three azido-bridged Mn(II) complexes (1, 2a and 2b) have been prepared with similar open-chain diazine Schiff-base as auxiliary ligands and characterized crystallographically and magnetically. The complex 2a is a 1D coordination polymer with a uniform double azido-bridged Mn(II) chains and the magnetic analyses reveal that the ferromagnetic coupling interactions are mediated through the double EO azido bridges. The complexes 1 and 2b consist of zigzag Mn(II)−azido chains in which the Mn(II) ions are alternately bridged by two EE and two EO azido ions. Magnetic analyses reveal that alternating ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions are mediated through the alternating EO and EE azido bridges in complexes 1 and 2b. We have also described an unusual isolation of two distinct coordination polymers with the same stoichiometry but significant different magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three azido-bridged Mn(II) complexes (1, 2a and 2b) have been prepared with similar open-chain diazine Schiff-base as auxiliary ligands and characterized crystallographically and magnetically. The complex 2a is a 1D coordination polymer with a uniform double azido-bridged Mn(II) chains and the magnetic analyses reveal that the ferromagnetic coupling interactions are mediated through the double EO azido bridges. The complexes 1 and 2b consist of zigzag Mn(II)-azido chains in which the Mn(II) ions are alternately bridged by two EE and two EO azido ions. Magnetic analyses reveal that alternating ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions are mediated through the alternating EO and EE azido bridges in complexes 1 and 2b. We have also described an unusual isolation of two distinct coordination polymers with the same stoichiometry but significant different magnetic properties.

cln_elements.content: Crystals of 1 were obtained by slow diffusion in an H-shaped tube. A methanol solution (5 mL) containing L1 (0.5 mmol, 0.113 g) and sodium azide (1 mmol, 0.065 g) was added into an arm of the H-shaped tube and a solution of manganese(II) perchlorate hexahydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.181 g) in the same solvent (2 mL) into the other arm, then about 20 mL of methanol was carefully added till the bridge of the tube was filled. Slow diffusion between the two solutions afforded orange crystals of 1 within 2 weeks. Yield 54.5% based on L1. Anal. Calcd. for C13H14N11MnBrO (%): C, 32.86; H, 2.97; N, 32.43. cln_elements.content:
The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1 and 2b were measured in the 2−300 K temperature range and are shown as χM and χM T versus T plots in Figure . The experimental χM T values for complexes 1 and 2b at 300 K are 4.03 and 4.07 emu mol−1 K, respectively, somewhat lower than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol−1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products decrease monotonically and tend to zero at low temperature, while the χM values increase to the rounded maximums at about 50 K and then decrease rapidly on further cooling. The final increase at very low temperature may be due to the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurities. These features indicate a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction in these complexes.

Because of the kinetic-to-thermodynamic transformation, it is difficult to obtain very pure sample of 2a. PXRD measurements indicated the bulk samples of 2a are always contaminated by a small quantity of an uncharacterized phase. But taking into account the ferromagnetic character of 2a (vide infra), the contribution of the small amount of impurity to the magnetic susceptibility should be negligible, and as will be seen below, the magnetic analyses based on the structure of 2a are satisfactory. But the preliminary magnetic properties are studied in the temperature range of 2−300 K. The experimental χM T values for complex 2a at 300 K are 5.31 emu mol−1 K, larger than the spin-only value (4.38 emu mol−1 K) expected for uncoupled high-spin Mn(II) ions. Upon cooling, the χM T products increase monotonically and smoothly to the maximum at about 27 K, and then decreases rapidly. The χM values increase monotonically, and below 3 K, the χM values decrease rapidly on further cooling (Figure ). These features indicate a dominant ferromagnetic interaction in complex 2a.
